thread.title: Tom Fox wins The Dallas Morning News staff photojournalist of the year
thread.title_full: Tom Fox wins The Dallas Morning News staff photojournalist of the year

author: Ron Baselice
title: Tom Fox wins The Dallas Morning News staff photojournalist of the year
text:
Tom Fox wins The Dallas Morning News staff photojournalist of the year Filed under Photos at Get Daily Dallas News Headlines Sign Up   
In his 26 years on staff at The Dallas Morning News , Tom Fox has won the news' Photographer/Videographer of the Year contest three times 
"Fox's photos and videos shimmer with a cutting wit, intelligence and a gift for finding moments when the world opens. His work blew us away," said the judge from The Dallas Morning News Journalists of the Year for 2016 contest. 
"Tom Fox captures the quiet moments of everyday life with a visual eloquence that allows readers to feel the moments. Tom uses light to guide our eye and his empathy is palpable in every image." 
"I am truly honored and humbled by the recognition. Over the years, I've been blessed with many successes at The Dallas Morning News, and none of that would have been possible without the support of my fellow photographers and editors. I work with some of the best in the newsroom business, and I'm appreciative of that foundation." 
Below is a slide show of Tom's winning photos and links to his two videos. Flower Mound McDonald's All-American basketball player Lauren Cox was The Dallas Morning News Player of the Year in 2016. Lauren signed with the Baylor Lady Bears. She was photographed Tuesday, March 8, 2016, in The Dallas Morning News studio. (Tom Fox/Staff Photographer) Supporters of Republican presidential candidate Donald J. Trump and New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie yelled for their attention following a rally at the Fort Worth Convention Center on Feb. 26, 2016. Trump was campaigning in Texas ahead of the Super Tuesday elections. (Tom Fox/Staff Photographer) The Rev. T.D. Jakes (right) of The Potter's House Church joked that if inmate Bev Vaughn (left) was any better at quoting Scripture, his job may be in jeopardy. Jakes and Dallas County Judge Clay Jenkins (center) visited with inmates at the Dallas County Jail about their experiences and what their goals are when they get out. They also met with Parkland Hospital administrators who work in the clinic there on Jan. 27, 2016, part of a "listening tour" to kick off a push for criminal justice reform and a lower jail population. (Tom Fox/Staff Photographer) Natalie Rojas, 8, strums a guitar found in the bedroom of her tornado damaged home on Mariner Drive in Rowlett on Jan. 8, 2016. Volunteer groups continued to clean up the tornado-ravaged neighborhood off Schrade Road. The guitar was a gift from her uncle. (Tom Fox/Staff Photographer) The Dallas Police Honor Guard followed the horse-drawn caisson carrying slain Dallas police officer Patrick Zamarripa for a ceremony at Dallas Fort Worth National Cemetery in Dallas on Saturday, July 16, 2016. Zamarripa was gunned down in an ambush attack in downtown Dallas over a week ago. Four Dallas police officers and one DART officer were killed and several survived. (Tom Fox/Staff Photographer) Dallas Cowboys players sprinted down the field as the warm up for morning practice at training camp in Oxnard, Calif., on Thursday, Aug. 11, 2016. (Tom Fox/Staff Photographer) Albuquerque boxing coach and gym owner Al Torres wiped down his son Josh Torres' face before his prime-time match against Mike Alvarado in a 147-pound welterweight fight at the Bomb Factory in Dallas on June 25, 2016. Fueled by faith, the underdog Torres fought the full eight rounds in the marquee match. After what some experts thought was a clear win by Torres, he lost in a majority decision. All was not lost for the evening. Josh, along with his wife, Arri Torres, told Al about their pregnancy. (Tom Fox/The Dallas Morning News) Tom Fox/Staff Photographer FOX Sports Southwest reporter Emily Jones and Texas Rangers left fielder Ian Desmond stood among the ice cubes and gumballs after Desmond was doused with cooler full of sport drinks following their 7-5 win at the Globe Life Park in Arlington on April 19, 2016. (Tom Fox/Staff Photographer) Artist Nathaniel Lawlor received some help from friend Jason Goodman as they pushed a fortune teller machine bearing Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump outside the Midtown Hilton in New York City on Tuesday, Nov. 8, 2016. When the red button was pushed, Trump's voice recited some of his famous and funny lines. (Tom Fox/Staff Photographer)
